The New York Times Magazine has published a number of controversial articles over the years, some of which have sparked significant backlash and criticism. Here are a few examples:

1. "The Flight from Conversation" by Sherry Turkle - in 2012, this essay argued that technology was making us less connected to one another and more prone to loneliness. However, some critics argued that it oversimplified the issue and ignored the positive effects of technology on human interaction.

2. "The Limits of ‘Believe All Women’" by Michelle Goldberg - in 2018, this piece pushed back against the idea that all women should be believed when they accuse men of sexual assault or misconduct. Many readers criticized the article for perpetuating skepticism and distrust towards survivors, while others praised it for raising important questions.

3. "Hollywood’s White Male Panic" by Maureen Dowd - in 2017, this piece examined the impact of the #MeToo movement on Hollywood and argued that men in the industry were feeling unfairly targeted. Many readers criticized the article for failing to acknowledge the systemic power imbalances that allow sexual harassment and assault to occur.

4. "The Case for Reparations" by Ta-Nehisi Coates - in 2014, this essay argued that the United States needed to consider reparations for the descendants of enslaved people in order to address the racial wealth gap. While the article was widely praised for its research and writing, it also sparked backlash from some readers who disagreed with the idea of reparations.

These are just a few of the many controversial articles that have appeared in the New York Times Magazine over the years.
